issue.title: first cut at CCI
issue.body: Should fix #7. CCI just activated for the project. Let's see....

comment.body: @vsoftco Please take a look at this PR: I'm confused: AppVeyor fails even though I didn't touch those config files. Second information: I added the code for MacOS testing but couldn't test it without the `.circleci/config.yml` accessible to CCI: I guess that only happens when merged. You might want to uncomment the MacOS job and see what happens. For now I take my hands off this PR. Please let me know if I should do sth/take a look again.
Thanks! Should work with higher Go versions, 1.11 is the minimum required

comment.body: Appveyor fails due to the stack issues with Rainbow V, I'll disable the later.

issue.title: Added OQS-OpenSSH demo
issue.body:
Hi @baentsch and @dstebila

Referring to issue #54. 

As we talked about, we have (the [ISE institute](https://www.fhnw.ch/en/about-fhnw/schools/school-of-engineering/institutes/institute-for-sensors-and-electronics) from [FHNW](https://www.fhnw.ch/en)) have created a docker demo image that uses your OQS-OpenSSH implementation.

The [README.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md) contains setup and general information while the [USAGE.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/USAGE.md) describes some more advanced use cases, like using this demo to connect to a remote OQS-OpenSSH instance.

I've added a new job for [CircleCI](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/.circleci/config.yml) for this demo image. The test it does is connecting to itself (localhost) using chosen PQC algorithms via OQS-SSH. Defaults are p256-dilithium2 and ecdh-nistp384-kyber-1024, chosen more or less randomly. Those algorithms may be changed by passing the SIG and/or KEM variables to the docker run command.
Return code is 0 if the connection to localhost using the ubkey method was successful, 1 otherwise.

I have **not** added OQS-OpenSSH to the "Push all images" step, I reckoned as you will be hosting the image I'll let you set that up properly.

Git history is squashed down to 1 commit, I do not want to bring my mess over :-)

Let me know if any adjustments are required.

comment.body: @mattcaswell Quick question: Is there any way to test (new) signature providers -- short of adding all "plumbing" like asn1_meth,  pkey_meth (i.e., effectively implementing https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/10512) wired to call into a (generic) signature provider? I wanted to put "real code" into the OQS sig provider to finally complete this PR but wonder how to trigger it... If it's not simple, please just say No; I'll then get going on 10512 for real.

There are some docs on some of this, e.g. see:

https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man7/provider-signature.html

https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man7/provider-keymgmt.html
Works like a charm on Ubuntu, almost on macOS (couldn't yet figured out how to install GoLang...) Thanks!!

Glad to hear that, Thanks. Now that the jobs are starting on CCI, you can actually re-run them with SSH access such as to log in to the running test machine and "look around" there, e.g., to check out how to install golang: 
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/104755973-70244e00-575b-11eb-9b52-0a05c1e31146.png)
Let me know if I should take a look (though I'm neither a Mac, nor golang "expert").

issue.title: Added OQS-OpenSSH demo
issue.body:
Hi @baentsch and @dstebila

Referring to issue #54. 

As we talked about, we have (the [ISE institute](https://www.fhnw.ch/en/about-fhnw/schools/school-of-engineering/institutes/institute-for-sensors-and-electronics) from [FHNW](https://www.fhnw.ch/en)) have created a docker demo image that uses your OQS-OpenSSH implementation.

The [README.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md) contains setup and general information while the [USAGE.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/USAGE.md) describes some more advanced use cases, like using this demo to connect to a remote OQS-OpenSSH instance.

I've added a new job for [CircleCI](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/.circleci/config.yml) for this demo image. The test it does is connecting to itself (localhost) using chosen PQC algorithms via OQS-SSH. Defaults are p256-dilithium2 and ecdh-nistp384-kyber-1024, chosen more or less randomly. Those algorithms may be changed by passing the SIG and/or KEM variables to the docker run command.
Return code is 0 if the connection to localhost using the ubkey method was successful, 1 otherwise.

I have **not** added OQS-OpenSSH to the "Push all images" step, I reckoned as you will be hosting the image I'll let you set that up properly.

Git history is squashed down to 1 commit, I do not want to bring my mess over :-)

Let me know if any adjustments are required.

comment.body: I'll take a look next week.

Thanks for the sample code and pointers! Now all of that is working nicely (sign/verify for OQS algs via EVP). But this still didn't trigger the `sig_get_ctx_params` functions (that necessitated the NID/AID logic we'd like to "detach" from OpenSSL internals)... I probably could explicitly call `EVP_PKEY_CTX_get_signature_md` along the same lines as your sample code above, but then... how do I know we deliver the right values back? Which OpenSSL functions would need this (and could tell me whether our return values are OK)?
All good, thanks, closing. Will replicate the config for liboqs-cpp as well.
